First Example

2018-04-26

Source: vignettes/first-example.Rmd
first-example.Rmd

Creating a chart

Let’s make a chart, then we’ll look at the bits-and-pieces we used to put it together.

library("altair")

plot <- 
  alt$Chart(
    r_to_py(mtcars)
  )$mark_point(
  )$encode(
    x = "mpg:Q",
    y = "hp:Q",
    color = "cyl:N"
  )

vegalite(plot, embed = vega_embed(actions = FALSE), height = 400)
#vegalite(plot, height = 400)

Installation

The first part of the code block is a call to load the package:

library("altair")

This assumes that your computer has a Python installation and an Altair installation. Please see the Altair installation page for more information on how to get up-and-running.

Once you have Altair working to your satisfaction in your Python environment, note the path on your computer to that Python executable. From Python:

# Python
import sys

sys.executable

It might return something like '/path/to/bin/python3.6'; you can use this value to set an environment variable to specify which Python environment to use. You might consider putting a line like this into your .Renviron file:

RETICULATE_PYTHON="/path/to/bin/python3.6" # *your* path will be different

For a more-detailed look at the ins-and-outs of Python installations, please see the reticulate page on Python Version Configuration.

When you restart your R session, the following code should “just work”.

library("altair")

has_altair()
#> [1] TRUE

Chart object

The next part of the code block creates a chart object:

plot <- 
  alt$Chart(
    r_to_py(mtcars)
  )

There’s a few things going on here. The first is that the altair (R) package exposes the Altair (Python) library using the variable alt. In the Altair documentation, the convention is to expose the Altair library through the varaiable alt:

# Python
import altair as alt

Accordingly, we expose the “same” variable, by default, as a part of the package-loading process.

The next step is to create the chart itself. In Python, we would use language like this:

# Python
plot = alt.Chart(...)

Here’s where reticulate does its job. It exposes Python objects as R S3 objects that behave like Reference Class objects. In practical terms, wherever you see a . in the Altair Python documentation, use a $ in your R code:

plot <- alt$Chart(...)

The argument to the Chart() function also merits some explanation. In Python, the function expect its data argument to be a Pandas Dataframe. The reticulate package offers us a function r_to_py(), which we re-export in this package. This function and its complement py_to_r() manage conversion back-and-forth between some common data-types “shared” by R and Python. The reticulate documentation has more information.

In our case, we are converting dataframes. Although the reticulate documentation suggests (or at least I interpreted) that the conversion would be made automatically, I found it necessary to call r_to_py() explicitly.

One important note - if your data-frame has variables that have dots in their names (think iris and "Sepal.Width"), this will cause you grief in Altair. My advice to you is to rename such variables before introducing such data to Altair.

Adding a mark

plot <- 
  alt$Chart(
    r_to_py(mtcars)
  )$mark_point(
  )

In Vega, “mark” is a similar concept to “geom” in ggplot2. In this case, we are saying we want to represent our data using points.

In Python, methods can be “chained” using the . operator ($ in our case), a little bit like how we use the %>% operator in R. To specify that we want points, we append $mark_point() to our Chart object.

Please note that there is nothing magical about the way that I have chosen to format the code. This is simply my way of trying to make it look (a little bit) like how we might “pipe” the code. In the future, it may be interesting to wrap operators like $foo using functions that could be piped, alt_foo(chart, ...).

Adding encoding

plot <- 
  alt$Chart(
    r_to_py(mtcars)
  )$mark_point(
  )$encode(
    x = "mpg:Q",
    y = "hp:Q",
    color = "cyl:N"
  )

In Vega, “encoding” plays a similar role to “aesthetics” in ggplot2. We are mapping variables in the data to scales in the plot.

What we see here is, in fact, a shorthand. As explained in the Altair documentation, there’s a longer version:

plot <- 
  alt$Chart(
    r_to_py(mtcars)
  )$mark_point(
  )$encode(
    x = alt$X("mpg", type = "quantitative"),
    y = alt$Y("hp", type = "quantitative"),
    color = alt$Color("cyl", type = "nominal") 
  )

Altair recognizes four types of data, "quantitative", "nominal", "ordinal", and "temporal". As a side note, the variable cyl could be called "ordinal", but I think the default color scale for "nominal" works better in this case. It remains an exercise for the author of this article to figure out how to specify color scales.

Displaying and Examining

Now that we have specified our chart, it remains to display it. This package provides a function vegalite() that takes a Chart object then renders and embeds it as an htmlwidget.

vegalite(plot, height = 400)

You can examine the chart-specification by using the examine() function, which wraps listviewer::jsonedit(). To use this function, you will need to install the listviewer package.

examine(plot)
